repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - First Phase of the Municipal
            Adaptable Program Loan : Uberaba Agua Viva Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the First Phase of the
            Municipal Adaptable Program Loan : Uberaba Agua Viva Project
            for Brazil were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, risk to development outcome was moderate, Bank
            performance was moderately satisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was moderately satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: in order to provide a timely response to
            Borrowers' needs, projects contemplating large civil
            works can be appraised on the basis of conceptual and
            preliminary engineering designs, but the project's
            costing, disbursement and implementation schedules need to
            clearly reflect this. Project design needs to ensure the
            coordination of civil works interventions so as to minimize
            their impact on the community. The use of an external
            management support firm can be positive in transferring
            knowledge to the local team, but the knowledge transfer can
            take time and a transition period is needed to ensure the
            local team is fully operational. Results frameworks need to
            be designed: (i) candidly to present what a project can
            actually achieve during its timeframe; and (ii) taking into
            account Borrowers' capacity for measuring results and
            the availability of reliable baseline data. The design and
            implementation of a strong and effective communication plan
            is a key instrument to address citizen demands regarding
            impacts from large infrastructure investments. Complex urban
            development projects can be managed effectively by
            medium-sized municipalities with a reasonable institutional
            and operational capacity. An integrated urban water
            management approach is effective, creates synergies among
            financing and implementation institutions, and allows local
            stakeholders to understand project objectives and results.
            The relevance of the World Bank's assistance for
            achieving impact and sustainability is high even when it is
            not the main source of funding.

Brazil - First Phase of the Municipal
            Adaptable Program Loan : Uberaba Agua Viva Project

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Municipal Lending Program -
            Uberaba (Phase 1) Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Municipal Lending
            Program - Uberaba (Phase 1) Project is to promote better
            living conditions for all residents of the municipality of
            Uberaba through the promotion of integrated urban
            sanitation, environmental preservation, and expanded parks,
            recreational and cultural opportunities. This restructuring
            paper responds to the request of the Municipality of Uberaba
            to amend the Loan Agreement for the Uberaba Agua Viva
            Project to encompass the following changes: (i) application
            of the Bank's safeguard policy OP 4.12 on involuntary
            resettlement linked to land acquisition activities, with no
            relocation of people nor displacement of economic
            activities; (ii) reduction in scope, specifically related to
            water supply activities under component one and a change in
            the name of the park under component two; (iii) revision of
            the results framework to reflect the reduced scope and to
            refine targets to the actual project's expected
            results; (iv) increase in the project's total cost
            through an increase of counterpart funds; (v) minor
            reallocation of funds between categories; and (vi) updating
            of the financial management reporting instrument for the project.

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Uberaba Agua Viva Municipal
            Project : resettlement policy framework

abstracts.cdata!:
The Recovery Project Environmental
            Uberaba River Basin and Revitalization of Water Supply
            System - Living Water Project, aims to promote better living
            conditions for all residents of the municipality of Uberaba
            through the promotion of integrated urban sanitation,
            environmental preservation, and expansion of parks and
            recreational and cultural opportunities. More specifically,
            the project has the following objectives: 1) restore
            degraded areas along the banks of water bodies located
            within the urban area of Uberaba; 2) eliminate the release
            of unpleasant odors in the city center; 3) provide
            theopulation strategies for development of leisure and
            recreation; 4) increase the supply of water while not
            overloading the current stock; and 5) reducing the incidence
            of waterborne diseases and outbreaks of communicable
            diseases spread by insects and rodents. The pattern that
            emerges from impact analysis is one of short-term negative
            impacts during project implementation that are more than
            offset by long term improvements. The implementation stage
            will concentrate the most negative impacts but also have
            some positive impacts. Impacts during project implementation
            will be augmented because work will be done in heavily
            trafficked commercial areas. The contracting of employees
            for the project will generate a number of significant
            impacts. Large public works project such as this one tend to
            generate a mass of short-term migrants who, employed with
            the project or not, bring increases in criminality,
            prostitution etc. as people mill around the area searching
            for opportunities. The mass of short-term migrants will also
            increase demand for public services. The noise/dust/traffic
            associated with construction will also negatively affect
            residents in all areas where construction will take place.
            The central city will suffer negative impacts while
            interceptors and canals are being installed. Negative
            effects will also be localized and temporary. A long-term
            impact of the Agua Viva program will be an improvement in
            the health conditions of city residents related to
            water-borne illnesses.
